While data center infrastructure was historically lacking in Africa, the continent’s burgeoning digital economy has recently led to a surge in data center constructions, with a projected market growth of 50% by 2026 compared to 2021 [2]. Nonetheless, data centers are notorious for their massive energy usage and water consumption, which have raised significant concerns even in developed countries such as the U.S. [3 –5]. More critically, the added pressure on local water resources is particularly acute in Africa, where many countries are already grappling with extended droughts and water scarcity challenges [6, 7]. Therefore, it is important to assess data centers’ water consumption in Africa, supporting healthy development of the data center industry for essential economic growth while ensuring responsible utilization of limited freshwater resources. In this paper, we address the critical gap in the literature and present a first-of-its-kind water ef- ficiency dataset for data centers in 41 African countries across five distinct climate regions. The dataset includes hourly estimates of water usage efficiency (WUE) for both direct and indirect water consumption over one year. We obtain these estimates by combining weather data from across Africa with the corresponding fuel mix data (i.e., the composition of energy sources in each country). We use our dataset to evaluate and estimate the water consumption of inference on two large language models, Llama-3-70B and GPT-4, in 11 selected African countries. Our findings show that writing a 10-page report using Llama-3-70B could consume about 0.7 liters of water, while GPT-4 for the same task may consume up to 60 liters. For a medium-length email of 120-200 words, Llama-3-70B and GPT-4 could consume about 0.13 liters and 3 liters of water, respectively. Interestingly, 8 out of the 11 selected African countries consume less water than the global average, mainly due to lower water intensities for electricity generation. However, water consumption can be higher in some African countries with a steppe climate than the U.S. and global averages, prompting more attention when deploying AI computing in these countries.

Our dataset is publicly available on Hugging Face. The rapid growth of artificial intelligence and digital services has led to a substantial increase in data center demand. While data center infrastructure was historically lacking in Africa, the continent's digital economy has led to a surge in data center constructions, with a projected market growth of 50% by 2026 compared to 2021. Data centers are notorious for their massive energy usage and water consumption, which have raised concerns even in developed countries. The added pressure on local water resources is particularly acute in Africa, where many countries face extended droughts and water scarcity challenges.

It is essential to assess data centers' water consumption in Africa, supporting the healthy development of the data center industry while ensuring responsible utilization of limited freshwater resources. Recent studies have addressed the growing water consumption of data centers and AI computing, but they have predominantly focused on regions with large data concentrations, such as the U.S. and Europe, leaving out Africa despite its rapid expansion of data centers and pressing challenges of water scarcity. We address this critical gap in the literature and present a first-of-its-kind water efficiency dataset for data centers in 41 African countries across five distinct climate regions.

The dataset includes hourly estimates of water usage efficiency (WUE) for both direct and indirect water consumption over one year. We obtain these estimates by combining weather data from across Africa with the corresponding fuel mix data. To demonstrate the utility of this dataset, we consider two recent large language models, Llama-3-70B and GPT-4, and compare their water consumption for inference in African countries with that in the U.S. and globally. Our results for 11 representative African countries show that writing a 10-page report using Llama-3-70B could consume around 0.7 liters of water, while GPT-4 for the same task may consume up to nearly 60 liters of water.

Interestingly, our results also suggest that 8 out of the 11 selected African countries have a lower water consumption than the global average for performing the same task, due in part to a less water-intensive fuel mix for electricity generation in these countries. Some countries, such as Morocco, are even less water-consuming than the U.S. However, the actual impacts of running AI model inferences on local water resources in these countries are still significant in light of the high water stress levels in African countries. On the other hand, some countries, such as Namibia, are more water-consuming than the global average, further compounded by the enduring regional water stress, which may prompt more attention when deploying AI services in these countries.

Our dataset is primarily based on the methodology and modeling of previous studies, which study WUE and AI model water consumption with a heavy emphasis on the U.S. data centers. We do not model supply chain manufacturing because this aspect often relies on generalized, less accurate data that may not reflect the unique operational practices of individual data centers or computing workloads. The methodology provides equations for modeling onsite WUE, which refers to water directly consumed/evaporated to cool down the facility for each unit of server energy consumption, and offsite WUE, which is also called the electric water intensity factor and refers to indirect water consumption by the generation of electricity that supplies each unit of data center energy.
